Terms

Terms have the highest priority in expression evaluation. In addition to regular immediate values and identifiers ( â†’ Tokens ) , they include the following.

true and false

true and false ( True and False ) are treated as integer values with values of 1 and 0, respectively.

Avoid comparing true and false with other expressions. For example, instead of doing something like if(true != getBoolean()), write it like if(!getBoolean()). This is because in logical expressions, "0 is false" and "non-zero is true," not "1 is true," and because TJS2 does not have a boolean type, automatic conversion between numeric and boolean types is not performed.

void

void indicates "nothing." It is used in various situations to represent "nothingness." It is different from null.
Newly declared variables (variables to which nothing has been assigned) have this value.
When treated as a string, it becomes an empty string ( '' ). When treated as a numeric value, it becomes 0.

It is recommended to use the === or !== (identity) operators to compare void values.

null

null indicates that while it is an object, it "does not point to any object." It is different from void.
Attempting to access a null object will result in an error.
By using the incontextof operator to change the context to null, the function will be executed on the context of the location from which it was called.

Example:
    var objmethod = obj.method;
    objmethod(); // Executed on the context of obj
    objmethod = objmethod incontextof null; // Change the context to null
    objmethod(); // Executed on this (i.e., the context at the calling position)

Infinity

Infinity represents infinity. To represent negative infinity, use -Infinity.

NaN

NaN represents Not a Number. It is a numeric value obtained when the result of a calculation is invalid.

super

super represents the superclass of that class within its methods or properties. An error will occur if it is referenced outside of class methods/properties or within a class that uses multiple inheritance.

global

global represents the global object. It allows access to variables declared outside of all blocks, classes, and functions that are not class methods.


Example:
    var v;
    function test(v)
    {
        global.v=v;  // Set the global v to the argument v
    }

this

this usually represents the object instance itself within its methods or properties.
The "context" specified explicitly or implicitly at the time of calling is designated as this.

Function Expressions

You can use function to write functions within an expression. Refer to Functions.

Array Expressions

You can use [ ] to describe an Array class object on the spot within an expression. Refer to the Array Class.

Dictionary Expressions

You can use %[ ] to describe a Dictionary class object on the spot within an expression. Refer to the Dictionary Class.
